metadata.titleEn: Multi-scale surface flux and meteorological elements observation dataset in the Haihe River Basin (Huailai station-automatic weather station-10m tower, 2013)
metadata.description:
The data set contains the observation data of the 10m tower automatic weather station on December 31, 2013 at 1 solstice on January 1, 2013.Station is located in huailai county, hebei province, east garden town, under the surface of irrigated corn.The latitude and longitude of the observation point is 115.7880E, 40.3491N, and the altitude is 480m.
The automatic weather station is installed on a 10m tower, the acquisition frequency is 30s, and the output time is 10min.The observation factors include air temperature and relative humidity (5m), and the direction is due north.The wind speed (10m), the wind direction (10m), the direction is due to the north;Air pressure (installed in waterproof box);Rainfall (10m);The four-component radiation (5m), the direction is due to the south;The infrared surface temperature (5m), the arm is facing south, and the probe is facing vertically downward.The soil temperature and humidity probe was buried 1.5m south of the meteorological tower. The soil temperature probe was buried at a depth of 2cm, 4cm, 10cm, 20cm, 40cm, 80cm, 120cm and 160cm. The soil moisture sensor was buried at a depth of 2cm, 4cm, 10cm, 20cm, 80cm, 120cm and 160cm.The average soil temperature was buried 2,4 cm underground.Soil hot flow plates (3) are buried in the ground 6cm.Processing and quality control of observation data :(1) ensure 144 data per day (every 10min). If data is missing, it will be marked by -6999;(2) eliminate the moments with duplicate records;(3) data that is obviously beyond the physical meaning or the range of the instrument is deleted;(4) the format of date and time is unified, and the date and time are in the same column.For example, the time is: 2013-6-10-10:30.From February 4 to February 27, due to probe problems, soil moisture data at depth of 20, 40, 80 and 120cm were wrong;From January 1st to January 3rd and April 25th solstice May 20th due to probe problems, soil moisture data at depth of 2, 4 and 10cm were wrong;From January 1 to May 10, soil moisture data at 160cm depth was wrong due to probe problems.Dec 11 - dec 31 data missing due to power converter damage.
Data released by the automatic weather station include:Date/Time, air temperature and humidity observation (Ta_5m, RH_5m) (℃, %), wind speed (Ws_10m) (m/s), wind direction (WD) (°), pressure (hpa), precipitation (Rain) (mm), four-component radiation (DR, UR, DLR, ULR, Rn) (W/m2), surface radiation temperature (IRT_1, IRT_2) (℃),Soil heat flux (Gs_1, Gs_2, Gs_3) (W/m2), multi-layer soil moisture (Ms_2cm, Ms_4cm, Ms_10cm, Ms_20cm, Ms_40cm, Ms_80cm, Ms_120cm, Ms_160cm) (%), multi-layer soil temperature (Ts_2cm, Ts_4cm, Ts_10cm, Ts_20cm, Ts_40cm, Ts_80cm, Ts_120cm, Ts_160cm) (℃), average soil temperature TCAV (℃).
Guo et al, 2020 is used for site introduction and Liu et al, 2013 for data processing.

File naming method: **** station-#### stations-xx tower, yyyy, where **** represents the site name, #### # represents the site type, xx represents the tower height (meters), yyyy represents the data observation year
Data usage: this data is tabular data, which can be opened and viewed by WPS, Ecxel and other software

background: Aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) is a key factor in surface flux estimations with remote sensing algorithms and/or land surface models. Originally, z0m is defined as the height where the wind speed, given by the extrapolation of the logarithmic wind profile, becomes zero. According to numerous observations, the variation range of z0m over different surfaces is large, from an order of 1.0 m over urban areas and mountainous areas, to an order of 0.1 mm or even 0.01 mm over smooth water body surfaces, ice and snow surfaces. The traditional way to calculate z0m is based on the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory, using wind profile measurements. In practical applications, especially for remote sensing models and land surface models, it is difficult to obtain z0m for a local or regional scale based only on station observations. Former researchers have proposed some parameterizations between the aerodynamic roughness length and the land surface properties [e.g., vegetation height, leaf area index (LAI), etc.], since wind turbulence is controlled by the structure and spacing of roughness elements (plants and other obstacles) on the land surface, and z0m describes the roughness characteristics of a surface.
research objective: Based on the data of the Xiaotangshan Experiment (Changping District of Beijing, China), which was conducted in 2002, 2004, and 2005 respectively, the objectives of this paper are: (1) to calculate z0m over different surfaces and analyze the directional characteristics of z0m over heterogeneous surfaces using an analytical footprint model; (2) to relate the estimated z0m over heterogeneous surfaces to roughness element characteristic factors, and present a heuristic parameterization of z0m as a reference for model parameterizations.
challenges: More data is needed for further discussions.
methods: This paper calculates z0m over several land surfaces, with 3 years of experimental data from Xiaotangshan. Individual z0m over each surface component (patch) is calculated firstly with the characteristic parameters of the roughness elements (vegetation height, leaf area index, etc.), then z0m over the whole experimental field is aggregated, using the footprint weighting method.
dataset: This experiment was carried out at the Xiaotangshan Experimental Station for Precision Agriculture (40°10′41′′N, 116°26′52′′E, 35 m above sea level) in Beijing. The observation period in 2002 was from 26 March to 23 April and the land cover was bare soil. In 2004, the experiment was carried out from 30 May to 7 July. In the southern sub-plot field, the land cover was bare soil between 30 May and 11 June, while the maize plants started emerging around 12 June. In 2005, the experiment was from 1 May to 10 June and the experimental layout was almost the same as that in 2004.
findings: The results show that z0m is direction-dependent, mainly due to the heterogeneity of the size and spatial distribution of the roughness elements inside the source area along different wind directions.

background: Sensible and latent heat fluxes are important indicators reflecting the intensity of heat and water vapor exchange between the land and atmosphere. They influence the energy balance between the land and atmosphere, provide material, dynamic, and thermal sources for weather systems at different scales, and affect the water cycle process between the land and atmosphere. Currently, there are many traditional methods for observing surface fluxes, such as the Eddy-Covariance system (EC), Bowen ratio-energy balance system, and aerodynamic methods. Among these, the Eddy-Covariance system is internationally recognized as the most reliable method for observing surface fluxes; however, its observation scale is relatively small, with spatial representativeness only on the order of tens to hundreds of meters. The Large Aperture Scintillometer (LAS), in contrast to traditional Eddy-Covariance systems, can obtain average sensible heat fluxes at a regional scale (from hundreds of meters to several kilometers). Because the observation scale of LAS matches well with satellite pixel scales and the grid scales of numerical weather prediction and climate models, the observations from LAS can serve as ground truth at the pixel/grid scale for remote sensing estimation models, numerical weather prediction models, and climate models, thereby optimizing and validating these models. The observation principle of LAS is based on the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory (MOST), which, combined with the atmospheric refractive index structure parameter C2n and related meteorological data, utilizes the stability universal function fT related to the temperature structure parameter C2T to obtain the regional average sensible heat flux at the surface.
research objective: Using the LAS-related data from Guantao Station (January to December 2009) and Arou Station (January to June and October to November), the applicability of the Monin-Obukhov similarity theory (MOST) in LAS observations was analyzed, and a quantitative assessment method for the applicability of MOST was explored.
challenges: Due to the influence of underlying surface cover types, flatness, water and thermal conditions, and weather conditions, it is difficult to achieve the ideal assumption of uniformity in practice. Currently, domestic research on atmospheric similarity theory mainly focuses on the similarity relationships of wind, temperature profiles, and turbulence variance. However, there is relatively little research on the similarity between temperature structure parameters and turbulence characteristics in scintillation methods.
methods: Before analyzing the applicability of the MOST theory to LAS data, preliminary processing of EC and LAS data is conducted. LAS, EC, and AWS data from the Guantao Station for the year 2009 (January to December) and from the Aru Station (January to June and October to November) are selected.
dataset:
Guantao Station (36°30′54″N, 115°07′39″E) is located in Hezhai Village, Guantao County, Hebei Province. Its observation site and surrounding underlying surface consist of farmland, including winter wheat, corn, and cotton, with winter wheat and corn being rotated. The growth period for winter wheat is from October to June of the following year, while the growth period for corn is from June to October, and for cotton, it is from May to October. This area represents a typical farmland underlying surface of the North China Plain. In the LAS source area, the area of winter wheat (corn) accounts for about 45%, while cotton accounts for about 47%. 

Arou Station (38°02′40″N, 100°27′53″E) is located in the valley area upstream of the Heihe River, and its observation site and surrounding underlying surface consist of typical alpine grassland, which is relatively flat. The vegetation height in the source area can reach 0.2 to 0.3 meters during the growing season.
findings: (1) Under unstable conditions, large-scale vortex motion, atmospheric turbulence development, and temperature scales can significantly affect the applicability of the MOST theory; (2) Two new methods for determining the applicability of the MOST theory have been established, namely factor analysis and temperature structure parameter methods, and it has been verified that these two judgment methods are reasonable and reliable.

background: For surface flux measurements, large aperture scintillometer (LAS) has become more and more popular in recent years. Compared with traditional observation techniques, it can measure surface fluxes on a larger scale (500 m to 10 km). At present, LAS observation is not common in China.
research objective: The daily and monthly variation of HLAS is analyzed. And the observation differences between eddy covariance system and LAS, need to be studied further combined with footprint model and energy unbalance of eddy covariance system observation.
challenges: There is much less agreement on the form which universal stability function fT should take. Further more, since the iteration process of HLAS can not be convergence when low wind speed and very stable conditions appearing at night, Wm \ - 5 is specified.
findings: Sensible heat flux (H) calculation with the LAS data of above measurements shows that the beam height of LAS and wind speed are sensitive factors for sensible heat flux measurement (HLAS), zero-plane displacement height is crucial unless the beam height is much larger than it, and Bowen ratio needs to be determined accurately over wet surface, while air temperature, air pressure and aerodynamic roughness length are not sensitive for HLAS. According to the observations mentioned above, LAS can measure surface fluxes both over homogeneous and heterogeneous surfaces.

Example.Answer: An example of a challenge is the limited spatial representativeness of eddy-covariance systems, which have a small observational scale of only tens to hundreds of meters. This limitation makes it difficult to match the scale of satellite pixels or model grid scales, thus affecting the accuracy of remote sensing estimates and model validations.

Definition.Question: What is the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory (MOST) and how is it applied in surface flux measurements?
Definition.Answer: Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory (MOST) is a theoretical framework used in surface flux measurements to relate turbulence to surface layer stability. It is applied in methods like eddy covariance and large aperture scintillometer (LAS) to estimate sensible heat flux by incorporating atmospheric refractive index structure parameters and related meteorological data.

Definition.Question: What is aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) and why is it significant in land surface models?
Definition.Answer: Aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) is defined as the height where extrapolated wind speed becomes zero, reflecting surface roughness characteristics. It is significant in land surface models because it influences surface flux estimations and depends on land surface properties like vegetation height and leaf area index.

Definition.Question: What are the typical challenges encountered in applying the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory (MOST) in real-world observations?
Definition.Answer: Challenges in applying MOST include achieving the ideal homogeneous surface conditions due to varying land cover types, flatness, and weather conditions. Additionally, there is less agreement on the form of universal stability functions, and conditions like low wind speed and high stability at night can complicate the iteration process in flux calculations.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in challenges faced when using eddy covariance systems versus large aperture scintillometer (LAS) systems for surface flux observations?
Comparison.Answer: Eddy covariance systems, though reliable, have a small spatial representation, leading to challenges in capturing larger-scale fluxes. LAS systems, on the other hand, can observe over larger areas, making them more suitable for matching satellite pixel scales. However, LAS faces challenges in determining universal stability functions and handling low wind speeds or stable conditions, which are not typically issues in eddy covariance systems.

Interpretation.Question: How can discrepancies between eddy covariance system and large aperture scintillometer measurements be interpreted to improve large-scale flux observation techniques?
Interpretation.Answer: Discrepancies between these measurement systems highlight the importance of considering factors like beam height, zero-plane displacement, and Bowen ratio in LAS measurements. Analyzing these differences can guide improvements in flux observation techniques, particularly in refining models for heterogeneous surfaces and understanding the energy balance in eddy covariance systems.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes inconsistencies in soil moisture data collected from various depths at meteorological stations, and how do these impact the overall dataset quality?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Inconsistencies in soil moisture data can arise from equipment malfunctions, such as faulty probes, which were noted at different depths during specific periods. These issues can lead to missing or incorrect data, affecting the dataset's completeness and accuracy.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it challenging to apply Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory (MOST) in large aperture scintillometer (LAS) observations over heterogeneous surfaces?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The application of MOST is challenging over heterogeneous surfaces due to variations in surface cover, flatness, and weather conditions, which can deviate from the ideal homogeneous assumption. These factors influence the reliability of temperature structure parameters and turbulence characteristics, requiring careful consideration and alternative validation methods.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the underlying causes for the difficulty in parameterizing aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) using station observations for regional-scale models?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Parameterizing z0m for regional-scale models is difficult because station observations primarily capture local-scale data. The roughness length varies significantly across different surfaces and is influenced by the spatial distribution and size of roughness elements like vegetation and obstacles, necessitating parameterizations that account for these heterogeneities.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of using multiple data collection methods, such as automatic weather stations and large aperture scintillometers, on the accuracy and scale of surface flux measurements?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using multiple data collection methods can potentially improve the accuracy and representativeness of surface flux measurements by covering different spatial scales and capturing diverse environmental conditions. Automatic weather stations provide high-frequency, localized data, while large aperture scintillometers offer measurements over larger areas, which might better align with satellite pixel sizes and model grid scales. This combination can enhance model validation and optimization but may also introduce challenges in data integration and consistency.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the implications of missing or erroneous data on the overall quality and usability of meteorological datasets collected from automated stations?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Missing or erroneous data can reduce the quality and usability of meteorological datasets by introducing gaps and uncertainties. These issues may arise from equipment malfunctions or environmental factors, as seen with soil moisture data errors due to probe problems. To mitigate these effects, robust data processing and quality control measures are essential, including flagging missing data, removing duplicates, and correcting physically implausible values. Ensuring dataset integrity is crucial for reliable research outcomes and model inputs.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the ultimate goal of collecting multi-layer soil moisture and temperature data at various depths in the context of meteorological observations?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal of collecting multi-layer soil moisture and temperature data at various depths is to understand the interactions between the soil and atmosphere, which can influence surface energy balance, water cycles, and provide essential data for improving land surface models and remote sensing algorithms. Such data help in understanding the vertical profile of soil conditions and its variability under different weather conditions, which is crucial for applications in agriculture, climate modeling, and environmental monitoring.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it necessary to implement large aperture scintillometer (LAS) techniques over traditional methods for measuring surface fluxes?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Implementing large aperture scintillometer (LAS) techniques is necessary because they can measure surface fluxes over larger spatial scales (from hundreds of meters to several kilometers) compared to traditional methods like the eddy covariance system, which is limited to smaller areas. This is particularly useful for matching the scale of satellite pixels and numerical weather prediction models, providing a more representative ground truth for these applications, and optimizing and validating remote sensing models and climate models.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to explore the aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) over heterogeneous surfaces using an analytical footprint model?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Exploring the aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) over heterogeneous surfaces using an analytical footprint model is important because z0m is a critical factor in estimating surface fluxes and understanding surface-atmosphere interactions. The variability of z0m across different surfaces and wind directions can significantly affect the accuracy of land surface models and remote sensing algorithms. By relating z0m to roughness elements and land surface properties, researchers can develop parameterizations that improve model predictions and better represent the complexities of natural environments in surface flux estimations.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can the aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) be calculated over different land surfaces, and what factors must be considered in these calculations?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) can be calculated using wind profile measurements based on the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory. Factors to consider include the characteristic parameters of roughness elements such as vegetation height and leaf area index. Directional characteristics of z0m over heterogeneous surfaces must also be analyzed using an analytical footprint model, as z0m is affected by the structure and spatial distribution of roughness elements along different wind directions.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements have enabled the automatic weather stations to collect detailed meteorological data at high frequencies in challenging environments?
Enablement.Answer: The installation of automatic weather stations on 10m towers with sensors capable of high-frequency data collection every 30 seconds, and outputting data every 10 minutes, allows for comprehensive meteorological data gathering. These stations include various sensors to measure air temperature, relative humidity, wind speed and direction, atmospheric pressure, precipitation, radiation components, infrared surface temperature, and soil moisture and temperature at multiple depths.

Enablement.Question: In what ways do experimental data and parameterization models expand the understanding of aerodynamic roughness length across different land surfaces?
Enablement.Answer: Experimental data from field observations, combined with parameterization models that relate aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) to roughness element characteristics such as vegetation height and leaf area index, help in understanding the spatial heterogeneity and directional dependence of z0m. These models allow for the aggregation of z0m across heterogeneous surfaces using footprint weighting methods, offering insights for model parameterizations.

Expectation.Question: Why might the application of Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory (MOST) in large aperture scintillometer (LAS) data collection be challenging under certain surface conditions?
Expectation.Answer: The application of MOST theory can be challenging due to the variability in surface conditions such as vegetation cover, flatness, water and heat conditions, and weather, which may not meet the ideal assumptions of uniformity required by the theory. In unstable conditions, large eddies, atmospheric turbulence, and temperature scales significantly affect the applicability of MOST.

Expectation.Question: What are the potential reasons for the need for additional data to enhance discussions on aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) estimation methods for remote sensing models?
Expectation.Answer: Additional data is needed due to the large variability in z0m over different surfaces and the difficulty in obtaining z0m for local or regional scales using station observations alone. Parameterizations that link z0m with land surface properties such as vegetation height and leaf area index require comprehensive datasets to improve model accuracy and applicability.

Expectation.Question: Why do large aperture scintillometer (LAS) measurements face challenges in achieving convergence during nighttime conditions with low wind speeds and stable atmospheres?
Expectation.Answer: During nighttime conditions with low wind speeds and very stable atmospheres, the iteration process for calculating sensible heat flux with LAS data can fail to converge. This is because the universal stability function used in the calculations lacks a widely agreed-upon form, leading to difficulties in obtaining reliable results under these specific conditions.

Judgmental.Question: How effective do you find the use of Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory (MOST) in determining the applicability of large aperture scintillometer (LAS) observations for surface flux measurements?
Judgmental.Answer: The use of Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory (MOST) is effective in determining the applicability of LAS observations for surface flux measurements, especially considering the effects of large-scale eddy motions, atmospheric turbulence development, and temperature scales on the theory's applicability. The establishment of new judgment methods, like factor analysis and temperature structure parameter methods, further enhances this effectiveness.

Judgmental.Question: What challenges do you perceive in using eddy covariance systems for surface flux measurement, particularly in terms of spatial representation?
Judgmental.Answer: The eddy covariance system is recognized as a reliable method for surface flux measurement; however, its spatial representation is limited to scales of tens to hundreds of meters. This presents a challenge in representing larger areas, which is why large aperture scintillometers (LAS) that provide regional-scale measurements over hundreds to thousands of meters are being considered to complement or validate remote sensing models and weather prediction models.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, how crucial is the role of aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) in improving the accuracy of surface flux estimations using remote sensing models?
Judgmental.Answer: The aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) is crucial for improving the accuracy of surface flux estimations in remote sensing models because it describes the surface roughness characteristics that significantly influence wind turbulence and energy exchange processes. Accurate parameterization of z0m, especially over heterogeneous surfaces, can enhance model estimations and is necessary for effective integration with remote sensing algorithms.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how data from different depths of soil moisture and temperature sensors can be processed effectively given potential sensor errors.
Assertion.Answer: The data processing involves ensuring quality control by marking missing data, eliminating duplicate records, and removing data that exceeds physical or instrument limits. Errors due to sensor issues are noted, such as incorrect soil moisture data at specific depths during certain periods. This careful documentation and error marking help in managing and processing the data effectively.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about how the aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) is accurately estimated across heterogeneous surfaces using only a few observational datasets.
Assertion.Answer: The estimation of z0m over heterogeneous surfaces involves calculating individual z0m values for each surface component using characteristic parameters like vegetation height and leaf area index. These are then aggregated using a footprint weighting method to account for the heterogeneity of the source area, as demonstrated in the Xiaotangshan Experiment.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how large aperture scintillometer (LAS) data is used to complement traditional eddy covariance systems in measuring surface heat fluxes.
Assertion.Answer: LAS can measure surface fluxes at a regional scale, matching satellite pixel scales better than the smaller scales of eddy covariance systems. By analyzing daily and monthly variations and considering factors like beam height and wind speed, LAS data provides a broader measurement scale, which can be used to validate and optimize remote sensing models and numerical weather prediction models.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore the data collection methods used for measuring aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) and discuss the challenges associated with these methods in heterogeneous land surfaces.
Request/Directive.Answer: The data collection for measuring aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) involves using wind profile measurements as per the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory. Researchers have noted challenges in obtaining z0m for local or regional scales based on station observations due to the large variation in z0m over different surfaces, which range from urban areas to smooth water bodies. The difficulty lies in capturing the heterogeneity of size and spatial distribution of roughness elements that influence z0m, especially in heterogeneous land surfaces.

Request/Directive.Question: Please discuss the methods and challenges of using the Large Aperture Scintillometer (LAS) for regional-scale surface flux measurements and its applicability in various terrain types.
Request/Directive.Answer: The Large Aperture Scintillometer (LAS) is used for measuring surface fluxes over larger scales, matching satellite pixel scales and numerical weather prediction model grids. The challenge lies in the requirement for ideal conditions like homogeneous terrain, which are hard to meet due to varying surface cover types, terrain flatness, and weather conditions. In applying LAS, researchers analyze its compatibility with the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory (MOST), noting that the theory's applicability is influenced by factors like large-scale vortex movement, atmospheric turbulence, and temperature scale.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify potential datasets that can be used to validate the aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) parameterizations over different surfaces and discuss their limitations.
Request/Directive.Answer: Datasets that can be used for validating aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) parameterizations include experimental data from the Xiaotangshan Experiment and LAS datasets from locations like Guantao and Aryu stations. These datasets provide surface component measurements, atmospheric conditions, and land cover types. Limitations include the need for more data for comprehensive analysis and the difficulty in obtaining accurate z0m values due to the heterogeneous nature of land surfaces and the influence of roughness element characteristics like vegetation height and leaf area index.
